channel.title: Robocode (Programming Game)
channel.description:
Robocode is an open-source game where you program your own robot in Java and fight others in an Arena. It's recommended for anyone doing java, doesn't matter how experienced you are. Technically, anything can be done :)
I would be doing this if i had more time on my hands.
http://robocode.sourceforge.net/

item.title: Robocode (Programming Game)
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Lothy:

We could take the idea though and write our own version. In reality, the only things that would need to be written to start are a protocol and an interface for the robot itself. Better yet, just a protocol could be designed and documented, and then people could write the actual bots themselves in a language of their choosing.

That actually sounds pretty awesome, I’d help out/compete in something like this if it was not language specific. It also kinda ties in with the community without being rs-related: it’s scripting (sort of), it’s a relatively simple thing to program and it is AI-centered (which bots should be).

Read full topic

item.title: Robocode (Programming Game)
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

[quote=“Galook, post:19, topic:154120”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=210537.msg1843868#msg1843868 date=1193359217]
Interesting, when I get time I will check this out, and we just might have to start some sort of competition or team.
[/quote]

It would seem fun, but if you ever did it, you would have to make sure nobody uses other peoples’ code. I mean, when we were doing this in our class, I worked hard for a few hours on my code, and someone else that was messing with it copied and pasted other peoples’ code he found. My bot got downed like every time, so robocode would be a pretty unfair competition seeing the nature of this site, I’m sure there would be atleast a few people who would enter the competition with something they didn’t work on themselves.

Robocode competitions are held on the same computer, there is no internet involved. Both competitors’ source for their bots are loaded onto the same machine and the bots run off of that. I don’t even know if there is a robocode version that allows people to compete over the internet (its been about 2 years since I checked though ). You can even have more than 2 teams bots running, up to like 16 robots or something around there, and none of the bots need to be the same, although they can be.[/quote]
We could take the idea though and write our own version. In reality, the only things that would need to be written to start are a protocol and an interface for the robot itself. Better yet, just a protocol could be designed and documented, and then people could write the actual bots themselves in a language of their choosing.

Either way, implementation of the various methods would be left to the individual.

Read full topic

item.title: Robocode (Programming Game)
item.dc:creator: @Galook Galook
item.description:
@Galook wrote:

Moparisthebest:

Interesting, when I get time I will check this out, and we just might have to start some sort of competition or team.

It would seem fun, but if you ever did it, you would have to make sure nobody uses other peoples’ code. I mean, when we were doing this in our class, I worked hard for a few hours on my code, and someone else that was messing with it copied and pasted other peoples’ code he found. My bot got downed like every time, so robocode would be a pretty unfair competition seeing the nature of this site, I’m sure there would be atleast a few people who would enter the competition with something they didn’t work on themselves.

Robocode competitions are held on the same computer, there is no internet involved. Both competitors’ source for their bots are loaded onto the same machine and the bots run off of that. I don’t even know if there is a robocode version that allows people to compete over the internet (its been about 2 years since I checked though ). You can even have more than 2 teams bots running, up to like 16 robots or something around there, and none of the bots need to be the same, although they can be.

Read full topic

item.title: Robocode (Programming Game)
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I think you are unaware what kind of numbers we are discussing here.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chess#Mathematics_and_computers:

The number of legal positions in chess is estimated to be between 10^43 and 10^50, with a game-tree complexity of approximately 10^123.

No one, anywhere has enough memory to store 10^123 of anything.

Read full topic

item.title: Robocode (Programming Game)
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

But chess has some amazingly huge gamespace, and you could not look very far ahead without running out of RAM. Not to mention you have to choose intelligent and correct values for pieces and game states. It is much more complicated than it sounds.

Checkers has a large gamespace as well, but the peices have pretty much equal value and it would just be simpler to do. Not to mention I am much better at checkers than I am at chess

Read full topic

item.title: Robocode (Programming Game)
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Chess couldn’t be that hard. I’d imagine that you’d have a collection for pieces that were ‘in danger’, and those pieces would be given a priority. The bot would obviously search so many moves ahead, and keep this collection up-to-date. It’d count the moves required to attack that piece in its current position, and if two pieces were in danger at the same time, it’d move the piece with the highest priority.

It’d do the same when attacking - it’d aim to take out the most powerful pieces (queen, followed by rooks/bishops and so on) in order, where possible. Of course, it might want to consider pieces already removed so that it can take pawns into account (before they reach the opposite end of the board and get replaced by a previously removed piece).

Read full topic

item.title: Robocode (Programming Game)
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I am about half way done with a framework that would allow different checkers players to complete against each other. I was going to go that route when I am done, chess is perhaps one of the most complicated games to choose, probably over the skill level of most people here.

Read full topic

item.title: Robocode (Programming Game)
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:13, topic:154120”][quote author=Lothy link=topic=210537.msg1844241#msg1844241 date=1193366735]
However, it’s a very interesting and unique concept. It’s a shame nobody here ever came up with some kind of programming competitions for this site, because it would be a lot of fun.
[/quote]

I’ve had a few ideas floating around, suggest something perhaps? :)[/quote]
Chess? Or perhaps our own version of this robot game that is server based.
Sure, the competitions wouldn’t be centered around cheating, but stuff like that can really challenge your skills. It’s easy to make something that plays a game, but it’s a completely different story when it comes to making a winner, which is where the fun comes into it.

Read full topic

item.title: Robocode (Programming Game)
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

sh!ft:

This just screams “EXPLOIT ME EXPLOIT ME!”

Having just looked at a tournament website, it would seem that you send your bot to someone to run against the other bots.

However, it’s a very interesting and unique concept. It’s a shame nobody here ever came up with some kind of programming competitions for this site, because it would be a lot of fun.

Read full topic
